toxins.name: Insoluble Calcium Oxalates, which form needle-like crystals known as raphides
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Mechanical Irritation: The crystals are bundled inside specialized cells called idioblasts scattered throughout the plant tissues.
    ◦ Ejection: When a cat chews or crushes the plant material, these idioblasts rupture, forcibly ejecting the sharp, needle-like raphides into the surrounding soft tissues of the mouth, tongue, and throat.
    ◦ Trauma: This action causes immediate physical trauma and irritation to any tissue the crystals contact, leading to rapid pain, swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and hypersalivation.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Distribution: These crystals are "scattered throughout the plant," meaning all parts chewed by the cat can cause injury.
    ◦ Self-Limiting Potency: The pain is immediate ("immediate pain"), which often serves as a deterrent, limiting the amount of plant material the cat actually swallows. While the reaction is painful and causes significant irritation, the prognosis is generally "good to excellent," and full recovery is often expected without major veterinary intervention unless airway swelling occurs.

symptoms.name: Oral Irritation (intense burning sensation, pain)
symptoms.notes: The cat may demonstrate this pain by pawing at the mouth or shaking its head. The crystals cause inflammation and redness (erythema) of the lips, tongue, and mouth.Hypersalivation

symptoms.name: Excessive Drooling (Ptyalism)
symptoms.notes: This is a physiological response to the intense irritation and burning in the mouth.Swelling (Edema)

symptoms.name: Swelling of the tongue, lips, and pharynx
symptoms.notes: Swelling of the tongue and throat can be significant. In rare cases, severe swelling of the laryngeal region (airway) can lead to respiratory distress.Difficulty Breathing (Dyspnea)

symptoms.name: Dyspnea
symptoms.notes: This occurs if the swelling of the tongue and pharynx obstructs the airway. While the overall prognosis for this plant is generally good, airway obstruction requires immediate veterinary attention.Vomiting and Diarrhea

symptoms.name: Vomiting and Diarrhea
symptoms.notes: These are general signs of gastrointestinal upset associated with the ingestion of the plant material.Anorexia

symptoms.name: Refusal to eat (Inappetence)
symptoms.notes: The cat often refuses to eat due to the oral pain and swelling.

treatments.name: Oral Decontamination (Rinsing and Wiping)
treatments.description: This involves physically removing any remaining plant material from the cat's mouth and thoroughly rinsing or wiping the oral cavity with water or a wet cloth.
treatments.notes: This is the immediate first step to help remove the needle-like crystals (raphides) that have embedded in the tissues. This relieves pain and prevents further irritation.

treatments.name: Airway Management and Oxygen Support
treatments.description: If the cat is experiencing respiratory distress, a veterinarian may provide supplemental oxygen or, in severe cases, secure the airway (intubation).
treatments.notes: This is critical but rarely needed. It is reserved for cases where the irritation causes severe swelling (laryngeal edema) that obstructs the cat's ability to breathe.

treatments.name: Administration of Demulcents (Calcium-Containing Products)
treatments.description: The administration of milk, yogurt, or other calcium-containing dairy products to the cat.
treatments.notes: Insoluble oxalates often bind to the calcium in dairy products. This helps aid the clearance of crystals from the oral cavity and esophagus and acts as a soothing agent for the irritated mucous membranes.

treatments.name: Fluid Therapy and Nutritional Support
treatments.description: The administration of fluids (subcutaneous or intravenous) or offering soft foods/liquids.
treatments.notes: This is used if the cat is refusing to eat or drink (anorexia) due to significant mouth pain, which can lead to dehydration. Most cases have a good prognosis and recover without extensive intervention, but hydration support ensures the cat remains stable while the mouth heals.
